facts: Rainbows are actually full circles, but we usually only see half from the ground.
Double rainbows occur when light bounces inside raindrops twice before exiting.
No two people see the exact same rainbow because everyone views it from a different position.
You can never actually reach the end of a rainbow - it moves as you move.
The colors of a rainbow always appear in the same order: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet.
Moonbows are rainbows created by moonlight - they appear white to our eyes but cameras can capture their colors.
The secondary rainbow in a double rainbow has its colors reversed.
Rainbows can only form when the sun is behind you and lower than 42 degrees in the sky.
Red appears on the outer edge of a primary rainbow because red light refracts the least.
Alexander's Dark Band is the darker area between primary and secondary rainbows.
Some people can see more than 7 colors in a rainbow due to genetic differences in color perception.
Water spray from waterfalls and garden hoses can create rainbows on sunny days.
Rainbows appear circular from airplanes because you can see the full circle.
The Greek goddess Iris was believed to use rainbows as bridges between heaven and Earth.
In Chinese mythology, rainbows were considered celestial dragons.
A rainbow's arc is always at a 42-degree angle from the direction opposite the sun.
Triple and quadruple rainbows are extremely rare but have been photographed.
Polarized sunglasses can sometimes make it harder to see rainbows clearly.
